summary: Small-town best friends Hallie, Chloe, Wren and Katie go online to try and conjure up the Slender Man -- a tall, thin, horrifying figure whose face has no discernible features. Two weeks later, Katie mysteriously disappears during a class trip to a historic graveyard. Determined to find her, the girls soon suspect that the legend of the Slender Man may be all too real.

If you go in with low expectations there are a few gems in here. The phone scare and the library had me with chills but scenes like the guys' house were unintentionally hilarious. 
The actresses do a pretty good job with what they were given.  But the problem is they don't particularly stand out.  Even in the grand scheme of things with the Slender Man himself, their story is not that special.
The writer was very limited on what they could do with Slender as he has no discernible personality.  He just goes after them and screws with them in the process.  His metrology could be compared to Pennywise the Clown from IT, but with much less flare. 
There is also a big theme of hopelessness throughout the film.  They didn't meet with a scientist (which is odd because they found their book) to find a way out.  At no point did they even try to come up with a clever way to get rid of him in the end. 

A few technical great spots but there are also scenes where it's too dark to see.

Watch if you want but don't expect much in terms of substance.

Perfectly scary film!
I will not lie, guys. The jump-scares genuinely got me all of the time! They were really creative on how they delivered them, and also the transitions afterwards were really clever and well made. 
The main details about this film that I enjoyed were the foreshadowing on the main villain. For example, during one of the scenes in the bedroom, you see Slenderman's shadow emerge behind them. How scary!
Furthermore, it is a very progressive film, as I thought all of the main characters were all diversified and well written. In addition to that, the main protagonists were all female, which should be a good standard for films to come. This is a good contrast to the new Ghostbusters film, which was criticised for having an all female cast, as the cost of good writing. This film delivers both; a good diverse cast and good detailed writing. 
Very good film and would recommend to anyone who is wanting to get into the genre!

I will now tell you what I liked and disliked about this film.

What I LIKED:
-Slender Man's design: 
I liked how they made this suit look like it's part of his body.

-The Soundtrack: 
It's one of those moments where the music from the film is better than what it came from.

-Javier Botet's performance: 
a spanish actor known for playing The Crooked Man from the 2016 film "The Conjuring 2" and Leper from the 2017 and 2019 films "IT Chapter 1" and "IT Chapter 2" plays the Slender Man in this film, and like always, Botet puts on a good performance.

What I DISLIKED:

- Screentime: 
Slender Man, The Character who's name is in the title, has three minutes of screentime. Seriously, Imagine if you had your own movie and you only had 5 minutes of Screentime.

-The Characters: 
They were flat like paper, Who would want to watch a horror film where some group of teenagers scream every 5 damn seconds? And due to them summoning Slender Man for some reason, their dumbass actions get themselves disappearing one by one.

-The Ending: 
Okay... What? So Basically this film ends with one of the characters getting teleported to the forest where the Slender Man is located, she encounters and gets chased by Slender Man, The character gets turned into a tree just to save her sister, and then the sister talks about how the slender sickness spreads or something and then the film ends. Like.. what?

-The PG-13 rating: 
This rating really bothers me, I don't remember Slender Man being a PG-13 Character... And this was probably the reason a fuckton of scenes were cut.

-False Advertising:
Lots and lots of scenes from the trailers ended up getting cut. hell, even a character named "Allison" ended up being cut,

At the end of the day, This Movie is pretty "meh" that really could've been better and I wouldn't recommend it.

I'm a big fan of Joey King, but she wasn't really in a positive to save the movie.

The production value is obviously there, the effects are even good, and there are several intense moments that should set the atmosphere, but I just couldn't bring myself to care.

The writing has to be to blame.  It's 4-5 shallow, empty characters with just enough flavor to tell them apart, and I just can't care about them.

The movie focuses on the subtly of it all, the growing madness that Slender Man instills in his victims without properly building the tension or showing the characters slowly losing it, which would have given good actors the ability to save it.  Instead they use a lot of "it happened offscreen" or sudden cuts to show a lose of time, and we get a character suddenly looking confused instead of taking the audience on a journey with the character.

Maybe it's not the writing, and maybe the editor just didn't know what they were doing?  "What are all these long dramatic series in here?  This is so boring!  *cut* Eh, they'll get the point."

With all the options out there, I just don't think this is worth your time.  I could tell you to just watch the 3rd act, and you'd probably get as much out of this movie as you're going to get from the beginning.

The film has some interesting ideas that are only slightly touched upon at the very end. The idea of Slenderman being like a virus who spreads due to more and more stories surfacing about him on the internet, causing more people to seek him out and become entrapped in his twisted mind games until he eventually kills them is a very interesting concept that the film sadly doesn't follow through with. The film instead devolves into a mess of sloppily used horror tropes like jumpscares, bland characters who only have a slight hint of depth, and terribly rendered CGI used to create the main villain. In the end, this all results in a film that you'll find ironically entertaining wrather than genuinely great.

Damn it.  Just, damn it.  You can do a good Slender Man movie, you can do a great Slender Man movie.  Really just take the concepts you see in something like Sinister, and add the creepiness of films like Ouija 2 and you're set.  What Slender Man should have done is been one of those films that plays on technological fears and senses of paranoia, and used it's scares with subtlety.  There's a new brand of horror a lot of films do now where there will just be something in the background, and they won't dwell on it, it'll just be there.  Maybe you'll see it, maybe you won't, and that's what's creepy about it.  That's perfect for Slender Man, that's really what was creepy about him in those original images that made him popular in the first place.  And at times, this movie almost does that.  The weird thing is there are glimpses of what could be a good movie in here, like the director knew what made Slender Man scary but then the studio said "no, more jumps scares, more Sony product placement", and now here we are, just another cheap teen horror movie like every teen horror movie.  Literally this is just another teen horror movie, it's got all the ingredients of one: over the top acting, jumbled editing, big CGI jump scares, Joey King screaming at things, all the ingredients.  It's so frustrating because Slender Man is one of our modern monsters and he is a good one and he can be so scary, but this movie doesn't know what makes him scary.  Watching it I went from hopeful, to bored, to frustrated, to pissed off, to just disappointed.

I'm going to admit: I had very low expectations going into this film and it somehow didn't even reach those. This movie isn't the so-bad-it's-good kind; it's very much the opposite. I wasn't entertained at all. The best thing this movie had was the titular antagonist, the internet phenomenon that is Slender Man. Even years after it stopped being relevant it still posessed a certain creepiness factor. And yet he was heavily underutilised, appearing in the flesh in only a couple of scenes. He mostly infulences the protagonists psychologically through dream sequences or some hallucionatinons but rarely do we see him actually doing something. It's merely implied and that is a big misstep. The movie is also filled with sequences that obviously lead to a jumpscare of some kind and there one can see the lack of creativity behind the scenes. The actors don't do the film any favors as well. They try their best, in particular Joey King, with the script they are given but it doesn't seem to work. The characters just aren't compelling at all. That along with the very incoherent plot make the film almost unwatchable. For the first, say, 15 minutes I was actually thinking that it wasn't that bad but after the first girl that disappears everything just goes downhill. I'd say there are a few solid creepy scenes in the film that showcase what it potentially could have been but it just seems incompetent at what it's trying to do in this final form. It's a 1 for me.

Technically speaking, this might not fully qualify as a movie. It's certainly a recording of actors talking and moving, but Slender Man lacks any pretense of artistic expression. Also, it somehow fails to meet even the criteria of a film genre that has already relegated itself to lower than substandard expectations. Month by month we see shitty jump-scare horrors all as indistinguishable from one to the next, promising some transient thrills with boring, boring, BANG dynamics. Yet it not only fails to tell a compelling story in any regard to its ill-timed and criminally (literally) insensitive boogieman, but it also fails to deliver in the already lazy formula it is reliant upon. It's an utter waste of scream queen Annalise Basso who goes missing within the first 15 minutes despite her being the actress with the most credentials. Joey King of The Kissing Booth takes center stage and does her best (which isn't all that great) with the anachronistic dialogue written by a 50 year old man trying his best to capture the spirit of high school aged girls.

Slender Man has moments that are solid and have the makings of being a terrific and truly scary film. It presents an eerie atmosphere, as the majority of the scenes are shot at night with dark lit rooms, fog slowly creeping in the background, and ventures into the deep unforgiving woods that forces us to constantly scan the background for a shadowy figure. The acting is sufficient, I thought Julia Goldani Telles stood out and played this role quite well. With all of this going for Slender Man, its main downfall is that it lacks a fluid story that captivates its audiences. The pacing is erratic throughout the film, characters are so busy that I was never able to connect with any of them. Despite some nice visuals and tense moments, the main villain Slender Man also fails to be scary, he comes across as a generic boogeyman that we never really learn much about. Overall, I didn't think this was a bad horror film, it definitely has certain qualities about it that passes as watchable, but I feel like a much better movie is somewhere deep in those woods.

I suppose this movie was inevitable.  So this is about a group of four high school girls.  They do a Google search for Slender Man, summon him like fools, and now they have to try to survive.  Now I do actually do like the lore of Slender Man... to an extent.  In a sense, it is the internet's version of a campfire story.  I think it's a fun to look for him in the background of pictures online, and I do enjoy playing the video games, as simple as they may be.  That said, I can sniff out a turkey pretty far in advance, and there was no real reason for this movie to be put into existence.  The mystique is largely what makes this character as effective as he is, so why are they making a narrative focused on learning more about him?  This was about as terrible as I was expecting, and may God help you if you were excited for this.  Right out of the gates, this starts off on the wrong foot with these girls.  They don't talk like natural people, they talk more like how adults think teens talk, and it is awkward.  It is not helped by the fact that these girls aren't the best of actors, which is hindered even further because nobody in this makes logical choices.  Not to get into spoiler territory (I just know there are people out there that don't want Slender Man spoiled for them), but there are way too many points where you will audibly talk to the screen, asking hard-hitting questions like: "why don't you go to the cops?" or, "why don't you talk to an adult?"  This is a folly of many a horror movie but here, it is considerably worse because it is so noticeable.  To further exacerbate things, in the smack dab middle of when these girls are dealing with Slender Man, they take a break to bicker about boys.  Why?  Because this is written by somebody who does not have a clear understanding of how sensible human beings operate.  I don't think that this is the worst thing in the world, it is just a very poorly conceived horror flick.  It is basic, and when this thing is finally wrapping up, there are way too many dream sequences for you to even start being scared.  They make up the rules as they go along, so much so that the rules in this universe aren't clearly defined enough so that you feel threatened.  It gets tedious with the amount of research they do on computers, and there is even bad lighting to boot.  Yeah, this is a big time waste of your time.

Slender Man (2 out of 5 stars). Slender Man had potential in actually being a creepy scary film. A tall, faceless, and long arms mysterious being does sound creepy when it is lurking in the forests, stalking people. The film fails to even being a scary movie. It has everything that fails in its clichÃ© of horror movies. Stupid teens, boring direction that lacks scares and consistent scenes. Lets not forget the plot does feel more like a rip off from The Ring movies. The characters are all bad and lacking in characteristics that you would root for. These teens made the stupid decision to watch a video of a slender man on a website. From there, Slender man is stalking these teens one by one. Luring them into the forest or traumatizing them to the part they go insane. Teens make the stupid decision and it is difficult to even care for them. Also, if it is a plot hole or something. But where are all there parents. They go walking around their homes on a school night, yelling and screaming cause something is coming inside their homes. And no adult supervision is found. Until, one of the kids ends up in a hospital and the parents finally show up out of nowhere. The direction is lacking comprehensive with its storytelling. Characters go missing when one of the girls is trying to reach her boyfriend. You really do not hear back about what happened to him. The acting is dull. Joey King, Julia Goldani Telles, Jaz Sinclair, and Annalise Basso were all tedious with their performance. The script also was lacking in characteristics with their characters. Which made it hard for you to even care for them. The plot was similar to The Ring. Except, they are being stalked by a mysterious tall, skinny, faceless man. It does have some creepy moments. But it fails with its clichÃ© horror storytelling. And the climax and third act gets lazy with its storytelling. That is not even sure how to end the film. With one character going insane in the hospital and decides to face the slender man herself. Overall, Slender Man is a bad film. It lacks scares and suspense. Characters make stupid decisions. Acting is boring. The direction is lazy and the script lacks in fleshing out their characters. Only good thing is Slender Man is kind of creepy.

Okay, Slender Man was one of the most anticipated movie of 2018.. I enjoyed playing the game and listening to these urban legends about him, but this movie was.. EH!!!!
Just to know, this review is gonna be a funny review actually.

Slender Man is directed by Sylvain White, written by David Birke and starring Joey King, Julia Goldani Telles and Jaz Sinclair.

The story is about a group of girls summoning Slender Man and when he got summoned, one of them gets missing, and the others trying to run away from him.. this is the whole story!

Now, that's what I call a horror-pranks film, it's full of unscary scenes, with Slender Man pranking these girls.. or poor girls.. how did you talk all these pranks from a man without a face?

First of all, let's count the dumb choices in this movie...
1. They summoned Slender Man from a website, by a link says "SUMMON HIM". I mean what kind of creatures can be summoned from a website?
2. To "summon him", you must watch a video and follow the instructions in the video, and when you're done, congratulation, Slender Man is summoned, go and have fun with him!
3. Slender Man is a good pranker! He made me laugh a lot with his pranks... What's dumber than making a pranker creature in a horror movie?

4. Oh, yeah, the cast was dumber than Slender Man.

5. Slender Man, please, grow up.. stop playing with the trees, it's noisy!!

6. The CGI of Slender Man was like a man with some toilet paper rolled around his face.

7. This message is for the developers of this "game", please, fix the glitch of the faces, and the horror-dreaming stuff.

8. One more thing, please, fix the performances too, cause they are bad!

9. The finale.. LOL!

10. And now, the dumbest thing in the movie award goes to... The script! Congrats to the script, it was super-dumb!

So to put my experience with this movie in context: I have a long history with the Slender Man mythos. I came across some of the Marble Hornets videos back in 2010 or 2011, before the game came out and the character became sort of a meme, and I became obsessed. I poured through every webseries and blog I could find. Searched for forum threads of photoshops and did research on similar historical iconography. I even made my own short film on the subject. The community that was built around this monster was truly fascinating. An instantly recognizable monster whose stories were being built by a disorganized group of horror fans and amateur writers and filmmakers spread out across the internet. It was rapidly evolving modern folklore, and it was really cool to watch. Nearly the whole community seemed to understand what made Slender Man scary, and if they added context or back story, it would always be small and it would always raise more questions. The less you know about him the better. There were no solid rules. Just various accounts of stalking and death. Going back, a lot of this writing is fairly mediocre outside of the bubble of that passionate bunch of people, though some of the stuff still really holds up. One of my prized possessions is the complete series of Marble Hornets on DVD signed by the guys who made it. So with all that being said, I am going to address this film in two different ways: firstly as a film fan, and then as a Slender Man fan.

This is a very bad movie. Just atrocious. Wow. Do not watch it. Damn the writing is just so godawful. This is a movie about a bunch of teenage girls that was written by a middle-aged man and it is painful to watch. They spout weird dad jokes, and the flow of their conversations is so stilted and weird. They talk about leaving town in only the most generic, general ways. When Slender Man gets brought up, of course one of them has never heard of it, and the rest must explain it to her and the audience. They're all incredibly stupid. There's a scene where they all just have to sit still and wear blindfolds, and because the writing is trite garbage, one of them moronically lifts her blindfold and looks straight at the monster. Dumb. The drunken father of one of the girls breaks into his daughter's friend's house and attacks a couple of children and then is back in his home no problems the next day. Ridiculous. The whole set up and plot is basically a straight rip-off of The Ring. They watch a video, and then they are cursed to be killed by a monster. Plot threads are picked up and dropped almost instantly. There's a very pointed line about one girl having a bunch of trophies, and it's spoken with resentment. It sounds like a line you're supposed to remember but this almost conflict is never brought up again. There is a person feeding them information through the internet whose identity is called into question several times that stops being relevant halfway through the movie and they never address them again. The editing is choppy and the dream sequences are generic. The effects are inconsistent, sometimes they're creepy but usually they're in your face and looking awful. The sound design is full of odd choices. There is a sequence where she hears something downstairs and you hear metal clanking to the floor. This is later revealed to not be the monster, but I couldn't help but imagine Slender Man sneaking through the kitchen and accidentally knocking a pot off a shelf and it made me laugh in the middle of a scene that was supposed to be tense. Some of the cinematography was okay. The actors were alright, they probably would have been good if they had anything to work with, the cast really deserved better.

And as a Slender Man fan? What a mess. The writer and the director obviously have no concept of what makes this monster scary. Watching Slender Man videos trains you to watch the background for him. One of the scariest things about the character is seeing him when the protagonist doesn't. In Marble Hornets, the characters would become paranoid about doing things they don't remember and would film themselves when they sleep. Leading to recordings of Slender Man watching them while they lay unconscious. Characters would walk through the woods and you would catch a glimpse of him in the background. It increases the paranoia. He's always watching. In this movie the only time you see Slender Man is when the characters do. It's so blunt force about it. Wouldn't want the audience to miss him. Got to have him front and center. Wouldn't want to leave anything for someone to notice on a second viewing. Well, that's not fair really. I suppose there is one time where we see him and the girls don't; when his shadow sneaks into their room like he's fucking Peter Pan. It looks so stupid, and it's not even consistent with how he normally works. As someone who obsessively researched the Slender lore and got so freaked out by the videos that I would see him out of the corner of my eye next to trees and street poles, I can tell you that just finding the videos is enough to get someone hooked. That's what the community means when they say that he spreads like a virus. You find out about him and you go deeper and deeper and then you share your story and he spreads. Like a disease. The writer of this movie read the virus thing and instead decided to make it that Slender Man is "a computer virus but for your brain." Stupid. Nonsensical. So I suppose he did do some research, they showed a couple of the original Victor Surge images. They have the woodcarving of the skeleton. There's a brief mention of shadow people. But they obviously didn't do much more digging than that. And then there's the videos. They decided to rip off The Ring and make it so that instead of someone just becoming consumed by thoughts of Slender Man after finding videos or blog posts, there's a whole video-based summoning ritual that people do at parties. Sort of a modern Bloody Mary. Then well after that they find all of the drawings that are usually indicative of someone completely corrupted by Slender Man, a "proxy" as most people call it. But that doesn't actually make much sense for the character at that point, so it feels more like an element they knew they had to include but didn't know where to include it. All the videos they watch are strangely highly edited, with a whole lot of cuts and music playing over them and circles edited in to point out ol' Slendy, once again they have to point him out every time he's there because subtlety is impossible for this movie and it doesn't trust its audience to pay attention. And all these videos are posted on some deep web site. Why though? There's no violent content. Why are they not on a YouTube style website? You know, like they are in real life? And to cap it all off. Ever wonder what happens to Slender Man's victims after he takes them? Want to know what happens to these mysterious disappearing people? HE TURNS INTO A TREE AND THEN ABSORBS THEM INTO HIS TRUNK I GUESS.

OKAY. SURE. WHY NOT? FUCK IT.

It's just such a waste of a good monster. Slender Man can be terrifying, Marble Hornets frightened me more than any other horror media back when I first found it. But this movie is not remotely scary. Slender Man can be fascinating, finding all the little clues strewn about writing by dozens of different creators made me feel like I was uncovering some great secret. But the lore in this movie is so blunt force and expository it doesn't spur any curiosity. And ultimately, Slender Man can be great metaphor. He's been used as a way of addressing child abductions, self-medicating, our broken medical system, emotional isolation, mental illness, and fear of the wilderness. In this movie he is just a generic monster in a generic monster movie. He's the Bye Bye Man. He's Annabelle. He's It Follows, but shitty. Don't watch this movie. It's not a good movie.

My first encounter with Slender Man was with the freeware online game, Slender: The Eight Pages, that went viral back in 2012 scaring the bejesus out of everyone that played it. Actually, what dared me to play the game was the YouTube videos of people playing Slender, watching their reactions of nervous laughter and all out fear. So, this meant I went into the screening assuming this was a horror flick based on the phenomenal game, but sadly no, and as was exiting the cinema accusing the production team of not even having played the game, disrespecting itâ€™s source material or totally missing out on some great potential. But, after a little research, I discover that the game itself was based on a recent folklore meme created by Eric Knudsen (credited as his pseudonym Victor Surge) back in 2009. Itâ€™s apart of this creepypasta movement that exploded via internet forums and chain letter style emails with copy and pasted (Hence the origin of creepypasta) images of folklore legends, many of which relating to ancient urban myths and horror stories. This being a competition to who could create the best paranormal images and so Slender Man was born in the Internet. I also discover that this isnâ€™t the first film to feature Slender Man with an American found footage film Always Watching: A Marble Hornets Story which starred the famed, lanky and gaunt Doug Jones back in 2015. And thereâ€™s a number of smaller independent films and shorts based on Slender Man. Iâ€™ve yet to watch any of these films so itâ€™s impossible for me to make any fair comparisons. So, I went in expecting a film based on the computer game and sadly was greeting with something totally uninspiring and unrelating apart from the scary no-faced character. But does knowing this might not have been inspired by the game make this film any better or forgivable? Hell, no! As a stand alone horror, itâ€™s terribly executed and unoriginal, snatching bits from other horrors like The Ring in terms of myth and more recently the Autopsy of Jane Doe in terms of imagery. So, four girls hear about a scary video that claims to have some connection to childrenâ€™s disappearances across the globe and so, they dare themselves to watch it during a sleepover, inviting a dark and sinister entity into their lives, the Slender Man. An urban legend that abducts children or sends them crazy with continually hauntings and nightmares. Itâ€™s a basic story which neednâ€™t be trashed with poor performances or poor editing. Iâ€™m partly in conflict as to which owes more to the failure of this film, because their performances are no way aided by the obvious chopped up ending which would have an effect on the entire film. The trailers clearly indicates the film had some serious re-edits with so many loose ends that they couldnâ€™t have been simply forgot about, because thereâ€™s some screenshots that hint at more of some of the characterâ€™s unfinished stories. But then I read about the controversy that spooked studios and distribution about promoting and even releasing the film. The Waukesha stabbing in 2014 where two 12year old girls stabbed a fellow classmate apparently to appease Slender Man and out of fear of him killing their families if they did not comply. When this film was announced, one of the fathers of the girls who committed the stabbing, urged local cinemas to refrain from showing the film, calling it â€œextremely distastefulâ€ And this isnâ€™t an isolated incident, there has been a number of acts of adolescent violence spurred on by the Slender Man myth. But ignoring the controversy, the film is poorly made and is not a good representation for director Sylvain Whiteâ€™s relatively small filmography. Itâ€™s super clichÃ©d with bad plot lines, poorly acted and has such a weak script, and even weaker scares. The script and story are just plain stupid most of the time, again maybe owing a lot to bad edits, but no one would venture into dark woods, or walk the street alone at night when under threat. The imagery isnâ€™t that terrible, trippy and subliminal at times but itâ€™s nothing new and isnâ€™t enough to save the film at all. Considering the amount of source material there is, and for me, just coming from the game; thereâ€™s so much potential that got sadly wasted and missed that makes me believe I could make a better Slender Man movie. Only thing I thought suited the film was some of the sounds, the tolling bells and the looming hum. This film is begging for a spoof, especially when one character prematurely expresses his sex face. Itâ€™s just one of the worse horrors Iâ€™ve seen lately, itâ€™s one of the worse films Iâ€™ve ever seen. Alright, alright, I'm a little intoxicated right now. But so what? I mean if anything, I did this backwards. I felt like this is the kind of movie that I'd have to be intoxicated to watch, but I feel really mean saying that...so, let's not say that! Instead, let's just say that this is definitely one of the worst movies I've seen this year. 

I don't really know where to start and I don't want to spend much time on this but let's get started. The screenplay is probably the worst thing about this film. I can tell this is the kind of film that was pushed out really quickly to make bank, but it came out a few years too late. This screenplay didn't really have a beginning, middle and end. The characters weren't given any distinctive quality traits that separated them from one another. There were obviously a couple of cool ideas here but it was just so rushed. It was an hour and a half but it flew by like a bullet. 

The other problem was that this film was mostly written in post. Most of its intense, 'scary' scenes were rapidly cut together and paired with bright flashing lights, iffy sound design, and lackluster animation. I felt like the editors were trying to sculpt something out of nothing and it just wasn't there. It sucks because the actors weren't too bad but this film tried to make scares out of nothing. 

To be honest I'd rather get back to drinking so I'm going to cut this review short. I normally write reviews to help myself become a better writer but I don't feel the need to elaborate more on this. Cheers!

As a former moderator on a creepypasta website, this is by far the funniest film I have ever seen. The established canon being torn to pieces, the cliche and overdone orchestral jumpscares and plot, and the complete lack of any substance had me busting my gut in laughter. Almost seeming like a parody of the mythos, this film is a must-see for anyone interested in creepypasta, just for the raw comedic value.

As it stands on its own, though, without any ironic enjoyment, the film is utter garbage. Four nondescript boring leads in a town that apparently has never heard of light switches, flashlights, or common sense, embarking on a soulless, incoherent plot about kidnappings, brain viruses that are like computer viruses(?), and the corniest acting and scenes this side of the millennium. If you want a genuinely good horror flick, then this movie will make you either fall asleep or contemplate jumping off a building.

If there was ever a time to capitalize on the creepy internet sensation of Slender Man, it would be, well, not now in 2018. Maybe seven or eight years ago, definitely not several years after the tendrilled, blank-faced figure hit peak popularity, and definitely not after a poor girl was assaulted by two impressionable young girls in his name only four years back. Well, here's Slender Man now, a terrible movie adaptation of an already worn premise that's torturous to watch in every single way imaginable.
You know exactly what kind of movie you're in for within the first few dialogues of Slender Man. The four "teenage" girls speak like they're forty-year-old men reciting their best Generation Z impressions, all while giving the spooky trees surrounding them a solid run contending for the film's most wooden performances. Lead character Hallie (Julia Goldani Telles) is an especially boring black hole of charisma that's impossibly hard to root for given her next-level stupidity and complete void of personality.
Where there's no logic in Slender Man's character development (which it doesn't really have to begin with), there's even less in its titular big bad. With the abilities to appear in dreams/visions, manipulate tree trunks and tree branches (?), as well as haunt social medias in a shameless rip-off of The Ring, none of the Slender Man's powers have any sort of correlation, sense, or palpable installation of fear. Also, he's got tentacles.
Really, unless you're thirteen years old and on some early 2010's scene, there's nothing scary about a very tall man without a face wearing a ([n] admittedly dapper) business suit. Apart from some truly horrid VFX more than a notch below the quality of a student film, the only frights arrive by way of the cheapest of the most leading of choreographed of jump scares harbored in inappropriately messy, nonsensible horror sequences.
Perhaps the most insulting part of Slender Man is the moral haphazardly slapped onto the epilogue. In a tasteless attempt at justifying its controversial existence, the film's closing monologue involves a character describing Slender Man's true powers as a virus preying on curiosity, specifically online obsession. It's an obvious nod to the 2014 tragedy in which two girls stabbed their friend to near death as an offering for the fictional online creation, but it's downright offensive the film thinks it has something important to say.
With awful acting, writing, directing, storytelling, and every other imaginable aspect that goes into movie-making, Slender Man is a film that lands dead on arrival. There's not even a trace of ironic fun to be had with it.

Slender Man is based off online stories about the titular supernatural being whose fame was born 9 years ago and died about as far back. In the film, a group of girls decide to summon the Slender Man to prove he doesn't exist, but when one of them disappears all hell breaks loose.Â 



Find a comfy seat, settle in, and try not to fall asleep as Slender Man is so thin there's barely enough substance to keep you awake. Nothing about this past the 15 minute mark is at all engaging. It starts off quite well where it does a fine job introducing its protagonists, setting up the legend behind the Slender Man character, and had me keen to see where it ends up heading. But where it goes isn't scary, suspenseful, or even barely interesting... it's a straight up bore and going into the third act I was fighting to stay awake. It progresses so agonisingly slow and the occasional attempt at a horror sequence rips away any suspense as oppose to introducing it. There really isn't much variety to the horror sequences either, one or two moments are unique in that they're not going straight for the jump-scare but rather the presence of something creepy in the background.

As time goes on and the Slender Man starts becoming more physically involved in the horror sequences it becomes even less scary. It's one of those situations in horror where I feel like a less-is-more approach would have worked much better in generating scares. Any time it looked like it was starting to build suspense it completely ruins it with a predictably timed jump-scare or by simply showing the Slender Man which completely took me out of the film every time.



I want to highlight the editing here which is at times absolutely shocking and also the basic progression of the story that at times didn't make sense from scene to scene. Some of the editing and scene transitions are noticeably dreadful and jarring to the point where I couldn't tell what I was watching in some action/horror sequences because of jarring rapid cuts. And it's not just the editing within sequences that's awful, it genuinely feels like at times entire scenes are missing as it cuts from one location to the next and I'm straight up lost. For instance, as I mentioned in the premise a girl goes missing, when this happens in the movie one second it's day time and she's there and then in literally the next scene it's late afternoon and she's now missing. It took me a bit of time to gather what had happened and it's not the only transition that is dreadfully executed. And then I did a bit of research and found that Bloody Disgusting is reporting that major scenes were cut from the film by Sony/Screen Gems in fear of backlash to their gruesome nature.Â 



As far as the performances go, none of them really stand out as being any good. The four lead teens are played by Joey King, Annalise Basso, Julia Goldani Telles, and Jaz Sinclair and none of them really make an impact. Annalise Basso is the one I'm most familiar with as she was great in both Captain Fantastic (2016) and Ouija: Origin of Evil (2016). However she really isn't given much to do and I'd say is wasted in the story. Slender Man Review: Slender Man tells the story of three high school girls who summon Slender Man through â€œa website videoâ€ (because they canâ€™t say YouTube or anything), a monster that looks like a pale, tall man with freakishly long arms and no face, after watching porn at a sleepover and thereâ€™s a lot of screaming and jump scares. Wow this was a terrible movie. I never expected much in the first place. When they first announced that the movie would be made I thought maybe they could make a decent horror movie out of it. Then the first trailer arrived. It was a bunch of random creepy images and didnâ€™t even involve Slender Man at all. Thatâ€™s when I knew it would receive horrible reviews. It currently has an 11% on Rotten Tomatoes, 29 on Metascore, and 3/10 on IMDb. The plot was horrible. Very predictable, a bunch of jump scares, stupid decisions, and many laughable moments. The cast was horrible except for Annalise Basso, who is actually a good actress. But the order of disappearances for the girls goes from best actress to worst actress. Because of that the whole ending was so painful to watch. It was pretty funny to watch. The last 5ish minutes was hilarious. Because I donâ€™t care Iâ€™m going to spoil it. The girl weâ€™re left with is freaking out because of everything thatâ€™s been happening so she goes to the woods to give her life to Slender Man so it can all end. When Slender Man goes in to full monster mode to take her she runs away screaming. Like a few seconds ago she wanted to give her life. Another hilarious moment with that girl is thereâ€™s a part where she goes over to this one guyâ€™s house and theyâ€™re about to have sex. She looks at his face and itâ€™s violently shaking with a smile and the room is spinning and sheâ€™s screaming. It was one of the funniest scenes in a movie Iâ€™ve seen all year. The last dumb scene Iâ€™ll talk about came earlier in the movie. Annalise (the good actress) went missing and the three girls go into the woods at night to get rid of something they love as a sacrifice to Slender Man so they can get her back. The girls are supposed to be blindfolded and not to look because if they see his face theyâ€™ll be messed up forever. Of course one of the girls gets scared so she takes off her blindfolds and sees him, which had horrible effects and looked dumb. Then itâ€™s just a bunch of screaming and tripping through the woods followed by fake jump scares. There is not much good I can say about the movie. The only things are that Annalise was a good actress for the 15 minutes she was in the movie and there was maybe two instances where it was sort of creepy. Honestly it couldâ€™ve been a good movie if they did a plot similar to the video game, like a found footage thing with the plot of the game. Instead we got some funny jumbled movie with bad acting from Julia Goldani Telles and Joey King (who has been in horrible horror movies recently). This movie is going to win some Razzie Awards for sure. Donâ€™t see it. Donâ€™t waste your money. If you want to watch laughable horror film then this is the movie for you. My Grade: D

Let me start out by telling you that I went to see this with some family members and my Dad actually fell asleep during the movie...
This movie is terrible, the only reasons I gave it half a star is because the camera work was really interesting and pretty okay, and the website won't let me give it zero stars.
The acting is terrible and unconvincing, the plot was empty, the story went barely anywhere, and the ending is abrupt and leaves a lot of loose ends. I have to say, the only thing that "scared" me was the noise and music build up to the jumpscares, but once you get into the rhythm of the movie it's not scary at all, because you expect the jumpscares, and that's really the only scary thing this movie has got going for it. One of the other issues I had was the lighting. I understand it's supposed to be a dark, scary movie with silhouettes and shadows, but some sets were so dark that you couldn't see what was actually happening. The other lighting extreme was when a character would be walking in a dark place and suddenly shine their LED phone torch right down the barrel of the camera. If the effect of this was to temporarily blind you, then it's spot on.
A few things in this movie actually made me laugh, like some of the scenes, acting, and a couple of the jump scares even made me giggle.
The only good thing about this movie was the camera work. There were parts of the movie where characters were experiencing hallucinations and nausea, and the camera work did an excellent job of portraying that feeling to the audience. Apart from that, it is not worth the cost of pop corn and tickets.
Overall, this movie is boring, cringey, too long, and uneventful. The acting, although hilarious at times, was unconvincing. I recommend saving your money and skipping this "horror" movie.

Just to preface, I don't feel good about criticizing Slender Man. It feels like telling a kindergartener that their fingerpainting is lazy and derivative. I wasn't expecting too much going into this movie. And within the first 10 minutes, I gathered enough to know that the movie didn't want you to expect much of it, either. I like to lump movies like this into a category I call Sleepover Horror, along with recent gems like Bye Bye Man, Wish Upon, and Truth or Dare. Sleepover Horror does not hold itself to very high standards and asks that audiences do the same. The only standard is that it must be PG-13, catering to young adolescents who want to be spooked with their friends under a pile of blankets on the couch on Saturday night. To be frank, I have a soft spot for these kinds of movies. My first forays into horror were films just like these from a previous era (circa The Grudge). And when you're 13, you don't know or care that they're mediocre; they deliver what you and your friends want. So I would never grade Slender Man with the same rubric as something like Hereditary. Apples and oranges.

But even the nostalgia of my younger years couldn't redeem this failed attempt at movie making. I actually think it started out fairly promising. The premise was good enough, the characters were good enough, and the atmospheric tension was good enough (also, props to Joey King for acting her heart out no matter what script she's handed). For me, the biggest stake in the heart of this movie was pacing. When we're dealing with Sleepover Horror, I can forgive a lot: bad acting, ridiculous dialogue, painful plot contrivances, exposition through text messages, etc. But I can't forgive boredom, which Slender Man dished out in full service. I was along for the ride until Hallie's date with Tom: perfectly fine scene, but I have no recollection of what happened after that. I blacked out. I can't remember anything, because nothing in the following scenes made any sense plot-wise and therefore blurred together in a feverish attempt to mimic "The Ring." I came to around the part where Wren's trying to jump out her window for some reason, but by that point, I was no longer invested. If Slender Man had shaved 15 minutes off of its runtime and trimmed some of its fat, I think I might have held out until the end. It was a 90-minute movie that felt much, much longer.

Not to pile more dirt on its grave, but I have a list of other minor issues with Slender Man that I want to get off my chest:

I don't even know if the writer's originally planned this script with Slender Man in mind as the Big Bad. The fact that it's called Slender Man is totally meaningless; the film barely addresses any of his lore. It may as well have been called Spooky Steve, or Creepy Creeper, or Bye Bye Man 2. If you're going to make a movie specifically about Slender Man, you should probably draw upon what made him creepy in the first place. Like how he's always stoically planted in the background; he never moves and you never see him up close. That shit can be really effective for spooks (see "Courage the Cowardly Dog" episode with Ramses and the slab). As soon as we see him up close, he's robbed of his power. He seemed like a ripoff of the Crooked Man from Conjuring 2, both in the way he looked and moved.

Not to harp on the mythos, but didn't they explicitly mention that Slender Man has the power to hypnotize his victims and lure them in? That seemed to work with Katie, but the other girls were lure-proof. They kept screaming and running away. Hallie even has a weird moment at the end where she's like "Take me, sir. I'm ready to die" and then immediately changes her mind and bolts.

Why did the nurses in the hospital wear old-timey uniforms?

This movie has a real lighting problem. Most of it is in so much shadow that you can't see the actors' faces (intentional?), and then it'll suddenly cut to, like, the surface of the sun. For viewers in a dark theater, this was torture (and it happened about every 5 minutes). Like in the woods scene, when they have flashlights and then shine their lights right into the camera and it feels like you're in a dentist's chair.

They couldn't decide who it's protagonist was. My vote would be for the younger sister Lizzy since she gets a great little voiceover at the end that attempts to tie things together with the final word "ya know?"

Hallie is always mentioning she has track practice but never goes to track practice. What are you hiding, Hallie?

Hallie's family dinner is really quiet, dark, and awkward. I hate when movies do this. Hereditary did it too, but it had the excuse that a huge tragedy had just occurred. Wouldn't you at least want to turn on a few lights and play some light dinner jazz?

This movie was absolutely terrible. It was like someone gave a very, very, VERY vague description of what Slenderman is, and the writers were like "Oh, yeah, that makes sense." Overall, this movie was garbage and a waste of my money. Before going to see this film, I had already predicted that it would be some cheesy and atrocious film rendition of the game Slender Man. Needless to say, my prediction was spot on. First of all, the timing for the release of this movie is way off. The movie should've been released when the urban legend of Slender Man was in its prime. Other than that, the story was extremely boring, cliche, and often times very predictable. Another cliche aspect of the film were its "horror" features. Slender Man was riddled with predictable jump scares and little to no psychological aspects. There were only a couple parts that truly scared me. When it came to the atmosphere, the film was okay at best. The dark and foggy forest, Slender Man's home, was truly creepy. This was partly complemented by the sound design including the blowing of leaves and the creaking of branches. However, these scenes still didn't make up for the atrocious overuse of jump scares. Another thing I was disappointed with was the acting. It wasn't the worst in the world, but it certainly wasn't great. Acting is really supposed to sell the plot to the viewer and make the movie more interesting, but the acting in this movie didn't appeal to me or make the movie's already boring plot interesting. It lacked substance and didn't really make the characters memorable. Speaking of characters, the character development in this film was awful. The four main characters were just your typical high school girls seeking adventure. As I've said before, there is nothing memorable about these characters. Lastly, I'd like to touch upon the editing. Everything was fine except the CGI. The CGI was horrendous and made the movie much worse than it already was. A simple solution to this would be to show the main villain less. Reason being because it wouldn't showcase the limited CGI effects and also introduce a more eerie, psychological horror-type aspect into the movie. Great horror flicks like The Blair Witch Project (1999) have done this and I don't see why this film can't. Overall, I believe this movie was outdated for its time, boring, predictable, and simply just a bad movie.

The plot dragged on for too long, with too few scares or reasons to care about the fate of the film's characters. Even worse, the lighting is so dark (even during daylight scenes) that I could barely see what was happening on the screen. There was barely any tension present in the film, as it failed to offer a frightening incarnation of the usually frightening creepypasta legend. 

The PG-13 rating is not the problem with the film. Other horror films with the family friendlier rating have proven effective at offering thrills and chills without tons of violence or gore (such as Poltergeist, Truth or Dare, and A Quiet Place) so please don't blame the MPAA rating for this film's faults.

I think what ultimately killed Slenderman was the studio and the distributor's fear of OFFENDING a society that THRIVES ON BEING OFFENDED. Naturally, the people that might take offense wouldn't watch it anyway, so it is the audience that ultimately pays the price. 2018 is the year of "finding something to be offended by", and the film's backers fell into this societal fad. 

I sincerely hope horror's recent return to the mainstream isn't further strangled by the "hashtag" society of prudes and wannabe victims that have pulverized the entertainment industry to the point where every movie and TV show feels like a political advertisement. 

Bottom line: Wait for an unrated home video release for this one...If there is one.

It's a reiteration of the vast majority of recent horror movies. Cringe-worthy "relatable" teens make poor decisions to further the story of an otherwise plotless movie. This steaming pile of poop is an uninspired cash-grab simply taking advantage of a household name to lure in viewers (seven years too late). If ten people see this movie, it will probably surpass the budget and make the producers a profit.  Utilizing a cast of future porn stars and prior homeless people (because who else would star in it), Slender Man is sure to make slender earnings in the box office.

A couple years ago, Slender Man, the fictional monster created by Eric Knudsen, came to the forefront of American culture. The creepy fiction inspired two adolescent girls to complete an act of ruthless violence that was more terrifying than any story. A quick search of the character reveals numerous accounts of the way this 21st-century boogie man abducts children. These stories are often accompanied with photoshopped images of the figure throughout history, adding to the mystery and allure of the character. 

It was only a matter of time before Hollywood would try to profit off of the character, so naturally, this Slender Man film was born. The film follows a group of high school students who accidentally summon Slender Man into their world. They watch a bizarre internet video filled with spooky shots of forests, pagan looking symbols, and otherworldly bells. Honestly, this reminded me of the VHS tape that is played in The Ring. A week later, one of the girls goes missing, and the rest of the group must face the Slender Man to try to get her back. 

For being based upon a character that has inspired so much imagined and real-life horror, Slender Man the movie isn't very scary. The film is plagued by horror movie cliche after cliche and an ending that was so inevitably mundane that I left the theater wondering why I had even bothered. Save for the wonderfully atmospheric shots and creepy forest settings, there really aren't many redeeming qualities to the film. We see this CGI monster far too often for us to really be scared of the unknown of it. Instead of getting behind the characters as they try to investigate the mythology and motivation of the Slender Man, I spent more time rolling my eyes at their terrible judgment and cringe-worthy dialogue.  There was a real opportunity to craft a modern horror classic based upon what is arguably one of the most terrifying spooks in recent years. What we get instead is a boring and uninspired movie that will have even the most die-hard horror fans wishing they had kept Slender Man away from the big screen.

It has its moments, but Slender Man is ultimately a dull affair.

What is really disappointing is that the first ten minutes or so are pretty good. We are introduced to the four main characters. (One of the positive points of Slender Man is its actors.) The dialogue and pacing is pretty good, but then things just fall apart. There are a lot of dull scenes of the characters talking, arguing, and investigating without much interaction with anyone else. It doesn't help that the rules to Slender Man are vague and confusing throughout, and the exposition is delivered haphazardly. The ending in particular is a muddled mess.

To its credit, the actual scares in this are pretty good. They do manage to capture what makes the Slender Man so scary in the first place. There are some really impactful visuals. The director is an artist when it comes to spooky forests and having Slender Man fading in and out of the background. (Although on the other hand, there is an annoyingly large amount of close-ups.)

As spooky and nice looking as this movie can be, the good bits are just too few and far apart. I can't recommend this.

Urban Legends are things that every middle school and high school kid, as far back as I can remember, have perpetuated through word-of-mouth and online rumors and storytelling in ways that are meant to inspire a sense of mystery and, in most cases, horror through describing beings and encounters just fantastic enough to be interesting while being close enough to reality to be truly frightening. The Slender Man is no different. I am in my mid-twenties and, from what I can remember, I first heard about the Slender Man phenomenon around my junior year of high school (2011). At the time, my younger middle school-aged brother was the type of kid that couldnâ€™t watch even the tamest horror movie without pissing himself. Some of his friends at school had told him about a tall guy with no face that would kidnap you if you stayed out too late (Iâ€™m paraphrasing). One night when we were leaving the local rec center, not even 500 yards from our front door, he downright demanded that we call our mom to get a ride home because, in his words, â€œItâ€™s too dark out. The Slender Man could come get us on the way.â€ This was, to me, the dumbest thing I had heard out of his mouth in a while, but I asked for details and he told me what he knew. I thought that this sounded like a cool story. Some supernatural tall guy that comes outta nowhere and steals kids during the night? Iâ€™m in. A movie based on this story could go one of a hundred different directions. They could have gone the ultra out-there route and had the Slender Man end up being an alien abducting people (The Fourth Kind, anyone?). They could have made a found footage movie (for less money), also in the woods, similar to the storyline we got, but in a more grounded way with way less computer and phone screen exposition. What did we get, you ask? (this is the part where you get my actual review) We got a 90-minute sequence of teenage girls looking back and forth from each other to their (Sony) phone/computer screens followed by 45 minutes of a CGI tree monster facetiming people before ultimately kidnapping them. There are some decent attempts at fear-inducing imagery early on in the film, many of which were heavily influenced by (read â€œripped off ofâ€) the Ring franchise, but nothing we havenâ€™t seen done before, better. Character development is almost non-existent. We know one girlâ€™s dad is an alcoholic (though it never plays into the plot) and another girl runs/ran track. That is the extent of an attempt made at fleshing out any of the characters in this movie. Many of the sequences taking place in old buildings or in the woods used sound to their advantage and were definitely high points in the theater experience. The notion that something might sneak up behind you after a crunching of leaves or creaking of floorboards is a whole hell of a lot more relatable and frightening than much of the on-screen CGI-heavy visuals in the final act. The ending of the movie, which I will not spoil here for those of you who have been waiting your whole lives for a Slender Man feature film, was one of the most rushed, laziest endings I have seen in a very long time. This leaves the viewer annoyed and ultimately willing to forget any of the slightly more positive areas of the experience in favor of remembering the movie for what it is; a forgettable throw-away with a solid concept wasted on bad storytelling, mediocre acting, and a closing sequence that would drop a student film a whole letter grade.

To say this film was mediocre would be the understatement of the millennium. "Slender Man" is the reason why moviegoers today are losing so much faith in the modern horror genre. ("A Quiet Place" is an immensely better 2018 horror flick.) People say Hollywood lacks originality these days, and you really can't blame them, especially when Sony of all companies makes a film based on an Internet creepypasta... from 2012.

I have a theory: had this film been made at the height of the Slenderman phenomenon 6 years ago, the effect would've been a bit stronger, and the film would've probably done slightly better at the box office. (This film has only been out for a day and I don't see it staying in theaters for more than a month.)

And now for the actual movie. The acting isn't too horrible, but that's not even the main issue. Any frightening characteristics still associated with our old pal Slendy are now gone. Rather than have our sharp-dressed antagonist be a horrifying, rarely-seen stalker that watches you from afar, they've made him into a physically destructive, confrontational, borderline-slasher villain, like a paranormal Michael Myers. Other than his trademark suit, nothing about this movie truly says SLENDER MAN. Not even the infamous circle-and-X logo makes an appearance. Even Slendy's edgy fanboy Masky is absent. (Fans of the "Marble Hornets" franchise will understand.)

Speaking of which, if you want a more effective and unsettling picture about this jaded internet meme, go watch the "Marble Hornets" videos on YouTube. The 2015 feature-length spin-off "Always Watching" is almost as bad as the 2018 film, so pick your poison, dear viewer.

In conclusion, getting murdered by Slendy would've been far less painful than this 93-minute embarrassment of moving pictures.

CreepyPastas. Love'em or hate'em, they're here to stay. And the one that spawned this film is one of the first & best!

SLENDER MAN.

This particular tale started out as a short story on the net. From there, it blossomed into a national phenomenon, in good ways, & bad. Does this film do ol' Slendy justice? I would say....a little, but not fully.

Despite being 1 & a half hours long, it felt a lot longer, it crept along at a snails pace which, I'm sorry to say, hurt the film overall. There were good parts, to be sure, but it took FOREVER to get to them! The film's atmosphere was that of a modern gothic mystery, but then it de-evolved into a clichÃ© slasher flick without the boobs or gore!

The cast did well with what they were given which, sadly, wasn't much. I did believe they were a group of semi-misfit teens who messed with something they didn't fully understand till it was too late. I just wish these young starlets had been given better material, better direction....really, just a better movie. They were given half a can of corn starch & 3 packets of hot sauce & told to make a meal, & they managed to make something at least edible.

The effects were fine, but not enough to save the film. Slendy looked as he was supposed to, & there were parts where reality was distorted in a way that made you question what you were seeing.

The music was generic, but harmless. The sound effects were a good blend of harsh tones & white noise meant to disorient & set your jaw on edge so you didn't know what to expect, it was a moderate high point.

Sadly, I can't recommend Slender Man to any hard core Slendy fans. All the elements are there, but there's just....something missing. It's like the difference between regular candy & soda, & the sugar free & diet stuff, mainly the aftertaste. It's not an insult to the Slender Man, because it's not even on his radar; it's a generic ghost story that someone crammed Slendy into, which resulted in, not a bang, not a whimper, but a dull "...meh." I have no choice, but to give it 2.5 stars outta 5. See it once for the curiosity; but once you see it.....it'll be pretty easy to un-see it.

Slender Man is truly one of the worst films I've seen in years.  The writing is clunky and on par with a first draft, the acting is stiff and phoned in, and there's little sense of direction to be found anywhere in the movie.  Slender Man himself looks like he's wearing a sock over his head.  Unfortunately, this movie is a complete flop in the horror department as well.  When they're not unintentionally funny, the scares are mostly flat and lame (but don't worry, the movie compensates with obnoxiously loud music).  Even if you get scared at first, you probably won't get scared by the end, because this movie is as repetitive as all get out.  As an example, there's a certain scene in which a character gets scared by Slender Man and then wakes up in bed, only to immediately get scared and wake up again.  Seriously.  It's enough to make me wonder if this film is intentionally bad, because I can't imagine that anyone who was making this film thought this was passable.  Above all, this "movie" is a feeble attempt to cash in on an internet trend that faded into obscurity long before the movie came out.

The performances were predominantly well done and the dialogue was not terrible.

The CGI was not terrible and was scarcely used, excluding the climax of the film, which unfortunately suffered from using the CGI so confidently on such a small budget.

The cinematography was well done in many scenes and made surprisingly well done transitions.

The film, however, was not scary. Well, not in the ordinary way that many people define it.

The film had many jumpscares, which unfortunately were very predictable and not very heart pounding at all. But it did scare in another way. 

It made me afraid in my own home. The fear of your safety being violated is something this film preys upon successfully. Although my heart wasn't pounding from suspense, I was instead incredibly paranoid when I returned to my own home. Some of the encounters are very well done, and many of them were in public or private places where danger would seem to be the least of your worries.

This film is different. It has some big plot holes and some iffy cgi, but the atmosphere and the lingering paranoia really sold it for me. 

Unfortunately not many may agree with me, due to the negative publicity the film recieved due to its origins.

A very cliche plot that plays out very (VERY) similarly to The Ring, this movie takes so much from so many other horror movies in the genre, one scene being very similar to an iconic Evil Dead scene even. But one of the most glaring problems is the black girl character, where in the trailer its shown that she stabs herself in the eye at school, however the movie completely cuts this scene to idk, keep it PG-13? For the kids? Well congrats, they've made it where the last scene with the black girl doesn't even show her dying, nothing. She's just gone for the rest of the movie w/o any explanation. And final point...not scary in the slightest. I was impressed by one scene near the end featuring Slender Man that made the film a bit more entertaining, but it just isnt nearly enough.

'slender man' is the worst movie I have ever seen. the acting is terrible, the writing is horrible, the directing is embarrassing. Sylvain white should never be allowed near a film production ever again. slender man is a popular character yet is utilized worse than the bye bye man. great opportunities missed in this unoriginal ripoff of truth or dare and the ring. the cinematography is so ugly and dark, it's hard to see most of the movie, and when you can see it it's ugly to look at. the camera shots are so lifeless, sometimes you ponder why sylvain white placed the camera where he did. the storyline doesn't make any sense, you don't know how much time has passed in the movie since randomly it's day and night. the source material is not respected in the slightest as slender man is barely in the movie and is not scary, he is utilized terribly. this movie isn't scary, jumpscares aren't scary, they're a cheap scare, and even those are barely in the movie. it's so predictable. this movie is however funny and should be seen as a comedy, the scares are so poorly done and unintentionally funny, the audience in my theater were laughing. the script is clearly written by someone who doesn't understand how teenagers talk or act. the first 20 minutes feel like an hour and is boring and the rest is funny and quick. if you do go see this movie, see it with a friend or something as this would suck to watch alone. This movie is an embarrassment and is one of the unintentionally funniest movies of the summer.
